key_points: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle have been awarded for deciding to limit their family to two children as a measure to reduce environmental impact.
The award was given by Population Matters, a UK-based charity focused on achieving a sustainable human population.
Population Matters described Harry and Meghan's decision as 'enlightened' and highlighted them as environmental role models.
The couple's children, Archie and Lilibet 'Lili' Diana, were born in May 2019 and June 2021, respectively.
A spokesperson from Population Matters commended the decision, emphasizing the benefits of smaller families for the planet.
Prince Harry has previously expressed concerns about climate change and the impact of having children on the environment.
In a Vogue interview and his documentary 'The Me You Can't See,' Harry spoke on the importance of leaving a better planet for the next generation.
Population Matters awarded a total of 10 recipients in recognition of their efforts to promote sustainability, coinciding with the UN’s World Population Day.
Other awardees include Emma Gannon, Nairashe Maritsa, and Wendo Aszed for their contributions to discussions on family size and empowerment.
Each award recipient, including Harry and Meghan, will be offered £500 to donate to a charity of their choice.
